titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Samuel Kravitt Photographs and Other Materials
titlestmt.author: compiled by Staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 11:24

did.unittitle: Samuel Kravitt photographs and other materials

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The materials comprise photographs, a photographic negative collection documenting life at Yale during World War II, exhibit files, and biographical information documenting the work of Samuel Kravitt as photographer.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This collection was previously known as the Samuel Kravitt Photographic Negative Collection Documenting Life at Yale during World War II (RU 668).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Boxes 1-8 were transferred from RU 668. Boxes 9-12 are the gift of Marcia U. Kravitt, 2008.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Samuel Kravitt Photographs and Other Materials (MS 1923). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright is retained by Marcia U. Kravitt for materials authored or otherwise produced by her husband Samuel Kravitt. After the lifetime of Marcia U. Kravitt, copyright passes to Yale University. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Samuel Kravitt was born in New Haven, Connecticut, in 1913. He left high school in 1929, intending to become a pilot. After borrowing a World War I aerial camera, however, he decided on a career in photography. From 1930 to 1931, he served as apprentice to Joseph Stone, a local portrait photographer. In 1932, Kravitt opened his first studio at age 19 in downtown New Haven. In the early 1930s, he was commissioned to document the lifestyle of the Shaker community in Hancock, Massachusetts. He subsequently relocated to New York and was staff photographer for the New York World's Fair Corporation from 1937 to 1939, documenting the construction of the Fair. Kravitt returned to New Haven in 1940, opening a studio in the Yale Record Building. He made a transition from still photography to filmmaking during the 1950s and in 1962 founded Associated Film Consultants, a New York-based independent production company. Kravitt died in 2000.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records are arranged by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials comprise photographs, a photographic negative collection documenting life at Yale during World War II, exhibit files, and biographical information documenting the work of Samuel Kravitt as photographer.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Use Restriction: Researchers must request cotton gloves from the Reading Room Service Desk before handling photographic negatives in this collection.
